tn.ref: Now some time later
tn.text: This phrase marks the beginning of a new part of the story and indicates that these events happened later, not that Naboth owned the vineyard later. If your language has a way marking the beginning of a new part of a story, you could consider using it here. AT: "Now this is what happened later" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

tn.ref: Naboth the Jezreelite
tn.text: This is the name of a man from Jezreel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: king of Samaria
tn.text: "Samaria" was the capital city of the kingdom of Israel and here represents the entire nation. AT: "king of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: May Yahweh forbid that I should give
tn.text: This phrase is an oath that emphasizes that what follows will not happen. AT: "Because Yahweh forbids it, I will never give" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: give the inheritance of my ancestors to you
tn.text: The land that his ancestors received as a permanent possession is spoken of as if it were an inheritance. AT: "give to you the land that my ancestors received as an inheritance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Why is your heart so sad
tn.text: Here "heart" refers to the entire person and his emotions. AT: "Why are you so sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Do you not still rule the kingdom of Israel?
tn.text: Jezebel uses this negative rhetorical question to rebuke Ahab. It can be translated as a positive statement. AT: "You still rule the kingdom of Israel!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: let your heart be happy
tn.text: Here "heart" refers to the entire person and his emotions. AT: "be happy" or "cheer up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: wrote letters in Ahab's name
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) she wrote Ahab's name on the letters. AT: "wrote letters and signed them with Ahab's name" or 2) the word "name" is a metonym for authority. AT: "wrote letters on behalf of Ahab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the wealthy who sat with him
tn.text: The word "wealthy" refers to wealthy people. AT: "the wealthy people who sat with Naboth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: seat Naboth above the people
tn.text: Having Naboth sit in a place of honor is spoken of as if it were having him sit above the rest of the people who were present. AT: "have Naboth sit in a place of honor among the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: let them testify against him
tn.text: "have them accuse him"

tn.ref: the wealthy who lived in Naboth's city
tn.text: The word "wealthy" refers to wealthy people. AT: "the wealthy people who lived in Naboth's city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: as was written in the letters
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "as she had written in the letters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: seated Naboth above the people
tn.text: Having Naboth sit in a place of honor is spoken of as if it were having him sit above the rest of the people who were present. See how you translated this idea in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:21:08|21:9]]. AT: "had Naboth sit in a place of honor among the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: sat before Naboth
tn.text: "sat in front of Naboth"

tn.ref: they carried him out
tn.text: Here the word "they" refers to the people of the city.

tn.ref: Naboth has been stoned and is dead
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "We have stoned Naboth and he is dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: that Naboth had been stoned and was dead
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that the people had stoned Naboth and he was dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Naboth is not alive, but dead
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize Jezebel's statement. AT: "Naboth is dead!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh came
tn.text: This idiom means that Yahweh spoke or has sent a message. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Have you killed and also taken possession?
tn.text: Yahweh asks this question to scold Ahab. AT: "You have killed Naboth and stolen his vineyard!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: your blood, yes, your blood
tn.text: This is repeated for emphasis.

tn.ref: Have you found me, my enemy?
tn.text: Ahab uses this question to express anger toward Elijah. That Elijah "found" Ahab likely refers to Elijah discovering Ahab's actions, not to finding his physical location. AT: "You have found me, my enemy!" or "You have discovered what I have done, my enemy!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: you have sold yourself to do what is evil
tn.text: A person being committed to doing what is evil is spoken of as if that person had sold himself to evil. AT: "you have dedicated yourself to doing what is evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: what is evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The phrase, "in the sight of" refers to someone's opinion. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:05|11:6]]. AT: "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: See
tn.text: "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you"

tn.ref: completely consume and cut off from you every male child and slave and free man in Israel
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of destroying Ahab's family and preventing him from having any decedents as if he were consuming these people like a fire would consume them, and cutting them off as one would cut a branch from a tree. AT: "destroy every one of your male children in Israel, whether slave or free" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will make your family like the family of Jeroboam ... and like the family of Baasha
tn.text: Yahweh will destroy Ahab's family like he destroyed the families of Jeroboam and Baasha.

tn.ref: Anyone who belongs to Ahab
tn.text: "Anyone who belongs to Ahab's family"

tn.ref: who sold himself to do what was evil
tn.text: A person being committed to doing what is evil is spoken of as if that person had sold himself to evil. See how you translated this idea in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:21:19|21:20]]. AT: "who dedicated himself to doing what was evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The phrase, "in the sight of" refers to someone's opinion. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:05|11:6]]. AT: "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: removed before the people of Israel
tn.text: Here "Israel" refers to all twelve tribes of Israel and not just to the northern kingdom. AT: "removed from the presence of the people of Israel" or "drove out of the land before the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh came
tn.text: This idiom means that Yahweh spoke or has sent a message. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Do you see how Ahab humbles himself before me?
tn.text: God uses this question to show Elijah that Ahab's sorrow is genuine. AT: "I have seen how Ahab humbles himself before me." or "Look at how Ahab humbles himself before me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: in his days ... in his son's day
tn.text: Here the word "days" represents the entire lifetime of a person. AT: "during his lifetime ... during his son's lifetime" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
